questions.text: All are true regarding cephalosporins except:
Patient is being administered i.v. quinine following which immediately he developed restlessness and sweating, the most likely cause is:
Which of the following drug is not used for methicillin resistant staph. Aureus
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Cefaclor is a second-generation cephalosporin, which belongs to the beta-lactam class of antibiotics. Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) is resistant to all beta-lactam antibiotics, including penicillins, cephalosporins (like cefaclor), and carbapenems. This resistance is due to the presence of the mecA gene, which encodes an altered penicillin-binding protein (PBP2a) that beta-lactams cannot effectively bind to. As a result, cefclor is ineffective against MRSA and is not used in its treatment.

Other Options Explained:

Cotrimoxazole (Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole) is often used for community-acquired MRSA infections and has good activity in many cases.

Ciprofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone, may have variable activity against MRSA. While not first-line, it may be used if the isolate is shown to be sensitive.

Vancomycin is a first-line agent for serious MRSA infections, especially those acquired in the hospital. It works by inhibiting cell wall synthesis through a mechanism different from beta-lactams, and MRSA strains are usually susceptible to it.
